text: The Furnishings of Solomon’s Temple
And he made an altar of bronze, twenty cubits \add was\add* its length, and twenty cubits \add was\add* its width, and ten cubits \add was\add* its height.

Then he made the sea of molten metal, from brim to brim \add it was\add* ten cubits, completely round. And \add it was\add* five cubits in height, and ⸤its circumference measured⸥\f + \fr 4:2 \ft Literally “and it measured a line all around it” \f* thirty cubits.

Under it \add were\add* figures of oxen all around it, ten cubits \add high\add*, encircling the sea all around. The oxen \add were\add* in two rows ⸤cast as one piece with it⸥.\f + \fr 4:3 \ft Literally “molten with its casting” \f*

\add It was\add* standing upon twelve oxen, three facing north, and three facing west, and three facing south, and three facing east. The sea \add was set\add* upon them from above, and all their hindquarters \add faced\add* ⸤inward⸥.\f + \fr 4:4 \ft Literally “into the house” \f*
And its thickness \add was\add* a handbreadth, and its brim \add was\add* like the working of the lip of a cup, the blossom of a lily. And it held three thousand baths.

And he made ten basins. And he set five on the south and five on the north in which to wash; they washed off the work of the burnt offering in them, but the sea \add was\add* for the priests to wash therein.
And he made ten golden lampstands according to their custom, and he set \add them\add* in the temple, five on the south and five on the north.
And he made ten tables and placed them in the temple, five on the south and five on the north. And he made a hundred drinking bowls of gold.
And he made the courtyard of the priests and the great outer courtyard and the doors for the outer court. And he overlaid their doors with bronze.
And he set the sea at the southeast \add corner of the temple\add*.

And Huram\f + \fr 4:11 \ft This is the spelling in Hebrew, though many translations have “Hiram” \f* made the pots, the shovels, and the drinking bowls. So Hiram\f + \fr 4:11 \ft The spelling (“Hiram”) is different here than in the previous occurrences \f* finished making the work that he made on the house of God for King Solomon:
the two columns, the bowls, and the two capitals on top of the columns, and the two latticeworks to cover the two bowls of the capitals that \add were\add* on top of the columns,
and the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks, two rows of pomegranates for the latticework, to cover the two bowls of the capitals that \add were\add* before the columns.
And he made the water carts, and he made the basins on the water carts,
and the one sea and the twelve oxen underneath it.
And Huram-abi made for King Solomon the pots, the shovels, the three-pronged meat forks, and all the utensils of polished bronze for the house of Yahweh.
The king cast them in the plain of the Jordan, in the clay soil between Succoth and Zeredah.
Solomon made all these utensils in great abundance, for the weight of the bronze could not be determined.
So Solomon made all the objects that \add were in\add* the house of God: the altar of gold; the tables upon which \add was\add* the bread of the presence;
the lampstands, and the lamps for burning according to the custom before the inner sanctuary, of solid gold;
and the blossoms, the lamps, and the tongs that \add were\add* of solid gold;

and the snuffers, the drinking bowls, the dishes, and the firepans, of solid gold; and the entrance to the house, the inner doors to ⸤the most holy place⸥, and the doors to the house of the temple \add were\add* of gold.
